intro: Cryptodiscus transcaspicus, commonly known as the Transcaspian cryptodiscus, is a rare flowering plant native to Central Asia. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes parsley and carrots, and is characterized by its finely divided leaves and small, clustered flowers. The plant typically grows in arid or semi-arid environments, often in rocky soils. It is known for its ornamental value due to its delicate foliage and is sometimes cultivated in botanical gardens. However, it is considered endangered due to habitat loss and over-collection.
